features.name: Ranger Proficiencies
features.desc: A ranger is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g} and with light armor, medium armor, and shields (except tower shields).

features.name: Favored Enemy
features.desc:
At 1st level, a ranger selects a creature type from the ranger favored enemies list. He gets a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against them.
At 5th level and every five levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the ranger may select an additional favored enemy. In addition, at each such interval, the bonus against any one favored enemy (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.
If the ranger chooses humanoids or outsiders as a favored enemy, he must also choose an associated subtype, as indicated on the table below. If a specific creature falls into more than one category of favored enemy, the ranger's bonuses do not stack; he simply uses whichever bonus is higher.

features.name: Combat Style Feat
features.desc:
At 2nd level, a ranger must select one combat style to pursue.
The ranger's expertise manifests in the form of bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feats{/g} at 2nd, 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th level. He can choose feats from his selected combat style's list, even if he does not have the normal prerequisites.
Every style can also choose the following feats: Dodge, Great Fortitude, Lightning Reflexes, Toughness.

features.name: Favored Terrain
features.desc:
At 3rd level, a ranger may select a type of terrain. The ranger gains a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Initiative}initiative{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Check}checks{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Lore_Nature}Lore (nature){/g}, {g|Encyclopedia:Perception}Perception{/g}, and {g|Encyclopedia:Stealth}Stealth{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill checks{/g} when he is in this terrain.
At 8th level and every five levels thereafter, the ranger may select an additional favored terrain. In addition, at each such interval, the skill bonus and initiative bonus in any one favored terrain (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.

features.name: Endurance
features.desc:
Harsh conditions or long exertions do not easily tire you.
Benefit: You gain +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Athletics}Athletics checks{/g} and +4 bonus on Fortitude {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}saves{/g} against fatigue and exhaustion.
You may sleep in light or medium armor without becoming fatigued.

features.name: Hunter's Bond
features.desc:
At 4th level, a ranger forms a bond with his hunting companions. This bond can take one of two forms. Once the form is chosen, it cannot be changed.
The first is a bond to his companions. This bond allows him to spend a {g|Encyclopedia:Move_Action}move action{/g} to grant half his favored enemy {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} against a single target of the appropriate type to all allies within 30 feet who can see or hear him. This bonus lasts for a number of {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}rounds{/g} equal to the ranger's {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier (minimum 1). This bonus does not stack with any favored enemy bonuses possessed by his allies; they use whichever bonus is higher.
The second option is to form a close bond with an animal companion. A ranger who selects an animal companion can choose one from the list of available creatures. This animal is a loyal companion that accompanies the ranger on his adventures as appropriate for its kind. A ranger's animal companion shares his favored enemy and favored terrain bonuses.
This ability functions like the druid animal companion ability, except that the ranger's effective druid level is equal to his ranger level –3.

features.name: Favored Enemy
features.desc:
At 1st level, a ranger selects a creature type from the ranger favored enemies list. He gets a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against them.
At 5th level and every five levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the ranger may select an additional favored enemy. In addition, at each such interval, the bonus against any one favored enemy (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.
If the ranger chooses humanoids or outsiders as a favored enemy, he must also choose an associated subtype, as indicated on the table below. If a specific creature falls into more than one category of favored enemy, the ranger's bonuses do not stack; he simply uses whichever bonus is higher.

features.name: Combat Style Feat
features.desc:
At 2nd level, a ranger must select one combat style to pursue.
The ranger's expertise manifests in the form of bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feats{/g} at 2nd, 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th level. He can choose feats from his selected combat style's list, even if he does not have the normal prerequisites.
Every style can also choose the following feats: Dodge, Great Fortitude, Lightning Reflexes, Toughness.

features.name: Evasion
features.desc: A character can avoid even magical and unusual {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} with great agility. If a character makes a successful {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Reflex saving throw{/g} against an attack that normally deals half {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} on a successful save, he instead takes no damage. A {g|Encyclopedia:Helpless}helpless{/g} character does not gain the benefit of evasion.

features.name: Combat Style Feat
features.desc:
At 2nd level, a ranger must select one combat style to pursue.
The ranger's expertise manifests in the form of bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feats{/g} at 2nd, 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th level. He can choose feats from his selected combat style's list, even if he does not have the normal prerequisites.
Every style can also choose the following feats: Dodge, Great Fortitude, Lightning Reflexes, Toughness.

features.name: Quarry
features.desc: A character can, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, denote one target within his line of sight as his quarry. He receives a +2 insight {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack rolls{/g} made against his quarry, and all {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}critical{/g} threats are automatically confirmed. A character can have no more than one quarry at a time.

features.name: Camouflage
features.desc: A ranger of 12th level or higher can, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Move_Action}move action{/g}, use the {g|Encyclopedia:Stealth}Stealth{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill{/g} to hide in any of his favored terrains, even in combat.

features.name: Improved Evasion
features.desc: This ability works like evasion, except that while the character still takes no {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} on a successful {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Reflex saving throw{/g} against {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g}, he henceforth takes only half damage on a failed save. A {g|Encyclopedia:Helpless}helpless{/g} character does not gain the benefit of improved evasion.

features.name: Improved Quarry
features.desc: At 19th level, the character's ability to hunt his quarry improves. He can now select a quarry as a {g|Encyclopedia:Free_Action}free action{/g} and his insight {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} to {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} his quarry increases to +4.

features.name: Master Hunter
features.desc: A ranger of 20th level becomes a master hunter. He can, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, make a single {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} against a favored enemy at his full attack {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g}. If the attack hits, the target takes {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} normally and must make a {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Fortitude save{/g} or die. The {g|Encyclopedia:DC}DC{/g} of this save is equal to 10 + 1/2 the ranger's level + the ranger's {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier. A ranger can use this ability five times per day, but not against the same creature more than once in a 24-hour period.

features.name: Demonslayer Favored Enemy
features.desc: At 1st level, a demonslayer must choose favored enemy (evil outsider). At 5th level and every time he advances his favored enemy {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g}, the demonslayer must advance his bonus against evil outsiders. In addition to the normal benefits of favored enemy, a demonslayer gains a bonus equal to half his favored enemy bonus on {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}saving throws{/g} against {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spells{/g}, {g|Encyclopedia:Special_Abilities}spell-like abilities{/g}, and supernatural abilities of evil outsiders.

features.name: Favored Enemy — Demons of Magic
features.desc:
At 1st level, a ranger selects a creature type from the ranger favored enemies list. He gets a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against them.
At 5th level and every five levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the ranger may select an additional favored enemy. In addition, at each such interval, the bonus against any one favored enemy (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.
If the ranger chooses humanoids or outsiders as a favored enemy, he must also choose an associated subtype, as indicated on the table below. If a specific creature falls into more than one category of favored enemy, the ranger's bonuses do not stack; he simply uses whichever bonus is higher.
Demons of Magic are the group of demons who prefer to use spells in battle. Some of the Demons of Magic are dretch, oolioddroo, and succubus.

features.name: Favored Enemy — Demons of Slaughter
features.desc:
At 1st level, a ranger selects a creature type from the ranger favored enemies list. He gets a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against them.
At 5th level and every five levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the ranger may select an additional favored enemy. In addition, at each such interval, the bonus against any one favored enemy (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.
If the ranger chooses humanoids or outsiders as a favored enemy, he must also choose an associated subtype, as indicated on the table below. If a specific creature falls into more than one category of favored enemy, the ranger's bonuses do not stack; he simply uses whichever bonus is higher.
Demons of Slaughter is a group of demons who use martial weapons and have a lot of attacks or special attack effects, such as sneak attack. Some of the Demons of Slaughter are babau, cambion, and incubus.

features.name: Favored Enemy — Demons of Strength
features.desc:
At 1st level, a ranger selects a creature type from the ranger favored enemies list. He gets a +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against them.
At 5th level and every five levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the ranger may select an additional favored enemy. In addition, at each such interval, the bonus against any one favored enemy (including the one just selected, if so desired) increases by +2.
If the ranger chooses humanoids or outsiders as a favored enemy, he must also choose an associated subtype, as indicated on the table below. If a specific creature falls into more than one category of favored enemy, the ranger's bonuses do not stack; he simply uses whichever bonus is higher.
Demons of Strength is a group of demons who use martial weapons and powerful attacks. Some of the Demons of Strength are balor, nalfeshnee, and vavakia.

features.name: Demonologist
features.desc: At 3rd level, a demonslayer gains insight into his Abyssal enemies. The demonslayer gains a {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} equal to half his {g|Encyclopedia:Class_Level}class level{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Knowledge_Arcana}Knowledge (arcana){/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill checks{/g}.

features.name: Expanded Spell List
features.desc: A demonslayer adds the following {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spells{/g} to his spell list: 1st — protection from evil; 2nd — protection from evil, communal.

features.name: Fiendish Quarry
features.desc: At 11th level, when a demonslayer chooses an evil outsider as his quarry, he can the forgo the normal +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} and instead treat his weapon as if it were {g|Encyclopedia:Alignment}good-aligned{/g} versus his quarry.

features.name: Improved Fiendish Quarry
features.desc: At 19th level, when a demonslayer chooses an evil outsider as his quarry, he can forgo the normal +4 {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} and instead treat his weapon as if it had the holy weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Special_Abilities}special ability{/g} while attacking his quarry.

features.name: Freebooter's Bane
features.desc: At 1st level, the freebooter can, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Move_Action}move action{/g}, indicate an enemy in combat and rally her allies to focus on that target. The freebooter and her allies gain a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on weapon {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} against the target. At 5th level and every 5 levels thereafter (10th, 15th, and 20th level), the bonus increases by 1. The freebooter's bane lasts until the target dies or the freebooter selects a new target.

features.name: Freebooter's Bond
features.desc: At 4th level, a freebooter forms a bond with her crewmates. This bond allows her to spend a {g|Encyclopedia:Move_Action}move action{/g} to grant her allies extra combat prowess when they work as a team. All allies within 30 feet who can see or hear the freebooter gain an additional +2 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack rolls{/g} when {g|Encyclopedia:Flanking}flanking{/g} for 1 minute.

features.name: Touch of Flame
features.desc: At 4th level, a flamewarden can cause his weapons to burst into flame. As a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, the ranger can grant a single weapon he holds the flaming {g|Encyclopedia:Special_Abilities}special ability{/g} for 1 minute; while under this effect, the weapon counts as magic for the purpose of overcoming {g|Encyclopedia:Damage_Reduction}damage reduction{/g}. A flamewarden can use this ability a number of times per day equal to 3 + his {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier. At 12th level, weapons affected by this ability gain the flaming burst special ability instead.

features.name: Spellcasting
features.desc: At 4th level, a flamewarden adds firebelly and summon small fire elemental to his ranger {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} list as 1st-level spells.

features.name: Spellcasting
features.desc: At 7th level, a flamewarden adds scorching ray to his list ranger {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} list as a 2nd-level spell.

features.name: Stoking the Embers
features.desc:
At 9th level, a flamewarden can fan the last spark of a recently slain creature's life force back into a full flame. Once per day as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, a flamewarden can {g|Encyclopedia:TouchAttack}touch{/g} the corpse of a creature to grant it the effects of breath of life.
Breath of Life: This {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} cures {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}5d8{/g} points of {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} + 1 point per {g|Encyclopedia:Caster_Level}caster level{/g} (maximum +25).
Unlike other spells that {g|Encyclopedia:Healing}heal{/g} damage, breath of life can bring recently slain creatures back to life. If cast upon a creature that has died within 1 {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}round{/g}, apply the healing from this spell to the creature. If the healed creature's hit point total is at a negative amount less than its {g|Encyclopedia:Constitution}Constitution{/g} score, it comes back to life and stabilizes at its new hit point total. If the creature's hit point total is at a negative amount equal to or greater than its Constitution score, the creature remains dead. Creatures brought back to life through breath of life gain a temporary negative level that lasts for 1 day.
Creatures slain by {g|Encyclopedia:Injury_Death}death{/g} effects cannot be saved by breath of life.
Like cure spells, breath of life deals damage to undead creatures rather than curing them, and cannot bring them back to life.

features.name: Spellcasting
features.desc: At 10th level, a flamewarden adds summon medium fire elemental to his ranger {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} list as a 3rd-level spell.

features.name: Burning Renewal
features.desc:
At 12th level, a flamewarden can use the cleansing power of fire to remove afflictions from his body, mind, and soul. When the flamewarden takes 10 or more points of {g|Encyclopedia:Energy_Damage}fire damage{/g}, he removes the following conditions: fatigued, shaken, sickened, exhausted, frightened, and nauseated. Additionaly, he removes {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}1d6{/g} points of {g|Encyclopedia:AbilityDamage}ability damage{/g} and 1d6 points of ability drain from the most {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damaged{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Ability_Scores}ability scores{/g} of his choice.
The ranger can use this ability only once each time he takes fire damage, regardless of how much damage it deals over the required amount. He can use this ability a number of times per day equal to 3 + his {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier.
If the flamewarden has fire resistance or immunity to fire, fire damage he would have otherwise taken still counts toward activating burning renewal.

features.name: Spellcasting
features.desc: At 13th level, a flamewarden adds flamestrike, volcanic storm, and summon large fire elemental to his ranger {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spell{/g} list as 4th-level spells.

features.name: Phoenix Blast
features.desc: At 16th level, if a flamewarden dies, his body explodes in a conflagration in a 20-foot spread. Each hostile creature in the area takes {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}10d6{/g} points of {g|Encyclopedia:Energy_Damage}fire damage{/g} unless it succeeds at a {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Reflex save{/g} ({g|Encyclopedia:DC}DC{/g} = 10 + half the ranger's level + his {g|Encyclopedia:Constitution}Constitution{/g} modifier) for half {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g}. The flames don't harm the flamewarden's allies, who instead are {g|Encyclopedia:Healing}healed{/g} 5d6 points of damage, and any poisons they are currently suffering are neutralized.

features.name: Phoenix Rising
features.desc: At 20th level, the flamewarden gains immunity to fire, and once per day, the flamewarden rises from the ashes of his own destruction 1 {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}round{/g} after dying. The flamewarden's body re-forms with all his equipment, and he returns to life with half his maximum {g|Encyclopedia:HP}hit points{/g}.

features.name: Archery
features.desc:
At 2nd level, the ranger can select from Point Blank Shot, Precise Shot, and Rapid Shot.
At 6th level, he adds Improved Precise Shot, Point Blank Master, and Manyshot to the list.
At 10th level, he adds Improved {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}Critical{/g} to the list.

features.name: Wind Treader
features.desc: At 4th level, a stormwalker can wreathe his weapon in lightning. As a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, he can grant a single weapon he holds the shock {g|Encyclopedia:Special_Abilities}special ability{/g} for 1 minute; while under this effect, the weapon counts as magic for the purpose of overcoming {g|Encyclopedia:Damage_Reduction}damage reduction{/g}. A stormwalker can use this ability a number of times per day equal to 3 + his {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier. At 12th level, weapons affected by this ability gain the shocking burst special ability.

features.name: Archery
features.desc:
At 2nd level, the ranger can select from Point Blank Shot, Precise Shot, and Rapid Shot.
At 6th level, he adds Improved Precise Shot, Point Blank Master, and Manyshot to the list.
At 10th level, he adds Improved {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}Critical{/g} to the list.

features.name: Archery
features.desc:
At 2nd level, the ranger can select from Point Blank Shot, Precise Shot, and Rapid Shot.
At 6th level, he adds Improved Precise Shot, Point Blank Master, and Manyshot to the list.
At 10th level, he adds Improved {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}Critical{/g} to the list.

features.name: Flash Step
features.desc: At 11th level, a stormwalker can move across the battlefield like a bolt of lightning. As a {g|Encyclopedia:Full_Round_Action}full-round action{/g}, he can transform into lightning and move to any unoccupied square within 50 feet without provoking {g|Encyclopedia:Attack_Of_Opportunity}attacks of opportunity{/g}. He makes a single {g|Encyclopedia:RangedAttack}ranged attack{/g} against closest opponent after this movement.

features.name: One with the Storm
features.desc: At 16th level, a stormwalker gains immunity to electricity.

features.name: Flash Shot
features.desc: At 19th level, when a stormwalker uses flash step, he can make two {g|Encyclopedia:RangedAttack}ranged attacks{/g} after his movement. Both of these {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} are made at his highest {g|Encyclopedia:BAB}base attack bonus{/g}.

features.name: Trapfinding
features.desc: An espionage expert gets a {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} equal to 1/2 her level on {g|Encyclopedia:Perception}Perception checks{/g}.

features.name: Undercover
features.desc: An espionage expert gets a {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} equal to 1/2 her level on {g|Encyclopedia:Persuasion}Persuasion{/g} (when used to bluff) and {g|Encyclopedia:Stealth}Stealth checks{/g}.

features.name: Ranger's Bond
features.desc: A ranger forms a bond with his companions. This bond allows him to spend a {g|Encyclopedia:Move_Action}move action{/g} to grant half his favored enemy {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} against a single target of the appropriate type to all allies within 30 feet who can see or hear him. This bonus lasts for a number of {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}rounds{/g} equal to the ranger's {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} modifier (minimum 1). This bonus does not stack with any favored enemy bonuses possessed by his allies; they use whichever bonus is higher.

features.name: Espionage Expert Magic
features.desc: While usually rangers use their {g|Encyclopedia:Wisdom}Wisdom{/g} to cast divine {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spells{/g}, espionage experts use the power of their personality. The main casting ability for the espionage expert is {g|Encyclopedia:Charisma}Charisma{/g}.

features.name: Espionage Master
features.desc: An espionage expert of 20th level becomes an espionage master. She can, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, make a single {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} against a favored enemy at her full attack {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g}. If the attack hits, the target takes {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} normally and must make a {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Fortitude save{/g} or die. The {g|Encyclopedia:DC}DC{/g} of this save is equal to 10 + 1/2 the espionage expert's level + the espionage expert's {g|Encyclopedia:Charisma}Charisma{/g} modifier. An espionage expert can use this ability five times per day, but not against the same creature more than once in a 24-hour period.

features.name: Point-Blank Master
features.desc: At 5th level, nomad gains Point-Blank Master {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feat{/g}, ignoring all the prerequisites.

features.name: Animal Companion
features.desc: Unlike normal animals of its kind, an animal companion's {g|Encyclopedia:Hit_Dice}Hit Dice{/g}, abilities, {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skills{/g}, and {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feats{/g} advance as the druid advances in level. If a character receives an animal companion from more than one source, her effective druid levels stack for the purposes of determining the statistics and abilities of the companion. Most animal companions increase in {g|Encyclopedia:Size}size{/g} when their druid reaches 4th or 7th level, depending on the companion.
